title: Californians Seek Adequate Space in TriBeCa. Which Did They Choose?
text:
Irene and Rick Hoefert were ready to upend their lives and move to New York from their longtime home in California. Their two sons had left for college, and a year ago Mr. Hoefert, who works in technology, accepted a job in Lower Manhattan.

“It’s a big move and late-stage career move,” he said. But the couple, both in their 50s, were ready to forsake “the California driving lifestyle for the walking city of New York, which I had mostly visited during business trips over the last 30 years.”

They liked the vibe, the neighborhoods, the people, the food. “The general energy in the city was very appealing to me,” he said, “at a time in my career when I had sold a business and gone through semi-retirement and thought, ‘What’s next?’”

They aimed to buy a dog-friendly home in or near TriBeCa, within walking distance of Mr. Hoefert’s office and near a park for Chester, their English golden retriever. “Chester is so used to having a doggy door and a whole side yard,” Ms. Hoefert said.

[Did you recently buy or rent a home in the New York metro area? We want to hear from you. Email: thehunt@nytimes.com]

The Hoeferts were looking for enough space to host their sons and overnight guests. But even with a budget of $2 million to $2.5 million, they found that many places felt small, especially compared to their three-bedroom house with a pool in the Los Angeles suburbs.

A real two-bedroom in TriBeCa pushed them out of their price range, so a one-bedroom with extra space made sense.

For about eight months, Mr. Hoefert lived in corporate housing in Battery Park City while Ms. Hoefert remained in California with Chester, visiting occasionally.

At an open house, they met Todd Vitolo, a licensed associate broker on the Columbia Vitolo team at Compass. He showed them many of the new developments in and around TriBeCa.
